{{multiple issues| {{Globalize|date=December 2010}} {{more refs|date=January 2017}} {{external links|date=January 2017}} }}
A '''cultural district''' is traditionally conceived as a well-recognized, labeled, [[mixed-use]] area of a [[Human settlement|settlement]] in which a high concentration of cultural facilities serves as the anchor of attraction.
A debate has emerged on the concept of the cultural district, promoting potentially ground-breaking initiatives, even if most of the literature has concentrated on urban clusters, cities of art and cities of culture.<ref>{{Cite book|title = Creative cities, cultural clusters and local economic development|author1=Cooke, P. |author2= Lazzeretti, L. |last-author-amp=yes |publisher = Edward Elgar|year = 2008|isbn = |location = Cheltenham|pages = }}</ref><ref>{{Cite book|title = Tourism, creativity and development|last = Richards, G., & Wilson, J. (Eds.)|first = |publisher = Routledge|year = 2007|isbn = |location = London|pages = }}</ref>
Facilities include: [[performance]] spaces, [[museums]], [[art museum|galleries]], artist studios, arts-related retail shops, music or media production studios, dance studios, high schools or colleges for the arts, libraries, [[arboretum]]s and gardens.{{fact|date=January 2017}} Because they are [[mixed-use development]]s, cultural districts incorporate other facilities such as office complexes, [[retail]] spaces and, occasionally, [[residential area]]s.
The creation of a cultural district implies [[collaboration]] between the arts and the local community. Cultural districts may be seen by local authorities as a way to revitalize the “brownfields” of the urban core: areas of abandoned buildings that encourage businesses and residents to leave the [[citie]]s.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.artsusa.org/information_services/research/impact_areas/arts_environments/001.asp |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2008-12-02 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20081201051356/http://www.artsusa.org//information_services/research/impact_areas/arts_environments/001.asp |archivedate=2008-12-01 |df= }} Cultural Districts, Americans for the Arts</ref><ref>Cultural Districts, ‘The Arts as a Strategy for Revitalizing our Cities’, Americans for the Arts, 1998</ref>
The developing theory of cultural districts increasingly conceives them as development models for local systems, where the term ‘district’ refers to supra-urban area.<ref name=":0">{{Cite journal|title = Learning to design cultural districts and learning from designing them|url = https://dx.doi.org/10.1080/09654313.2015.1133565|journal = European Planning Studies|date = 2016-01-19|issn = 0965-4313|pages = 1–19|volume = 0|issue = 0|doi = 10.1080/09654313.2015.1133565|first = Alberto|last = Francesconi|first2 = Claudia|last2 = Dossena}}</ref><ref>Sacco, P. L., Tavano Blessi, G., & Nuccio, M. (2008). Culture as an engine of local development processes: System-wide cultural districts (Art and Industrial Design Working Papers). University IUAV of Venice. Retrieved from <nowiki>https://www.researchgate.net/publication/234167196</nowiki></ref><ref name=":1">{{Cite book|title = Advanced Cultural Districts. Innovative Approaches to Organizational Designs|last = Francesconi A.|publisher = Palgrave-McMillan|year = 2015|isbn = 9781137555342|location = Basingstoke|pages = }}</ref> At supra-urban or regional level the complexity of a cultural district is even more marked than at urban level, due to potential interdependencies among a greater multitude of actors.<ref>{{Cite journal|title = Referent Organizations and the Development of Inter-Organizational Domains|url = http://hum.sagepub.com/content/36/3/269|journal = Human Relations|date = 1983-03-01|issn = 0018-7267|pages = 269–284|volume = 36|issue = 3|doi = 10.1177/001872678303600304|first = Eric|last = Trist}}</ref> A useful approach towards a deeper understanding can be to conceive cultural districts as [[complex adaptive system]]s.<ref name=":0" /> Indeed, complexity is definitely not a [[management fad]] and fashion, a mere metaphor or methodology, but a deeper perception of reality.<ref>{{Cite journal|title = Application of Complexity Theory to Organization Science|url = http://pubsonline.informs.org/doi/abs/10.1287/orsc.10.3.215|journal = Organization Science|date = 1999-06-01|issn = 1047-7039|pages = 215–215|volume = 10|issue = 3|doi = 10.1287/orsc.10.3.215|first = Arie Y.|last = Lewin}}</ref> Organizations are classically seen as purpose-driven entities with a structural form, exhibiting a certain degree of order and determinism. Such a linear top-down approach to analysis and design, however, exhibits many limitations when used for organizational settings characterized by a complex web of interdependencies.<ref name=":1" /> The view of a cultural district as a complex adaptive system suggests new ideas and approaches for policy-makers, designers and managers. It also opens up debate on issues of organizational design and change.
==United States activities== More than 90 cities in the [[United States]] have planned or implemented cultural districts, positioning the arts at the center of their urban revitalization efforts.{{fact|date=January 2017}} All cultural districts are unique, reflecting their cities’ unique environment, including history of land use, urban growth and cultural development. There is no standard model. Most cultural districts are built to take advantage of other city attractions such as historic features, [[Convention (meeting)|convention]] spaces and parks and other natural [[amenities]].
Structural considerations within or near the district, [[community]] leadership and social forces all influence the development of a cultural district and the type of [[district]] that results. Factors influencing the siting of cultural districts include: perceived need for urban revitalization, existing investment, property value and preexisting cultural facilities.
Unlike a cultural center or a [[shopping mall]], a cultural district comprises a large number of property owners, both public and private, who control the various properties involved, hence a structural [[complexity]]. The [[effectiveness]] of the coordinating agency in guiding the direction of the cultural district varies according to its size, budget, mandated functions and degree of authority, resulting in widespread variation in the coordinated cultural programming and administration services offered by cultural districts. The coordinated [[Government agency|agency]] appointed for the district must work carefully to ensure inclusiveness of concerns and to balance potentially conflicting interests.
Cultural districts offer two major types of [[tertiary sector of the economy|service]]s: one targets the arts community, providing [[marketing]] /promotion, [[box office]] services and property management; the other targets the district’s business and property owners, offering urban [[design]] and development services or administrative support.
The excitement and attraction of a cultural district is a high mixture of interesting things to do, places to see, and places to visit (both cultural and noncultural), across the day and evening.
Some artist-activists are promoting the concept of a "Naturally Occurring Cultural District," or NOCD, patterned after the demographic concept of a [[naturally occurring retirement community]]. A NOCD "supports existing neighborhood cultural assets rather than imposing arts institutions somewhere new," according to Tamara Greenfield, co-director of NOCD-New York. Co-director Caron Atlas explained: "If a cultural district has emerged 'naturally,' then it grows from, builds on and validates existing community assets rather than importing assets from outside a community."<ref>Urban Omnibus, [http://urbanomnibus.net/2010/11/naturally-occurring-cultural-districts/ Naturally Occurring Cultural Districts], Nov. 17, 2010</ref> Indeed, different conceptions of cultural districts include self-organization and emergence in different degrees (e.g. Lazzeretti, 2003; Le Blanc, 2010; Sacco et al., 2013; Stern & Seifert, 2007). Many authors argue that districtualization is essentially spontaneous and that the conditions for formation can be recognized and sustained, not created from the top.<ref name="Lazzeretti 635–648">{{Cite journal|title = City of art as a High Culture local system and cultural districtualization processes: the cluster of art restoration in Florence|url = http://onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1111/1468-2427.00470/abstract|journal = International Journal of Urban and Regional Research|date = 2003-09-01|issn = 1468-2427|pages = 635–648|volume = 27|issue = 3|doi = 10.1111/1468-2427.00470|first = Luciana|last = Lazzeretti}}</ref><ref>Stern, M. J.,&Seifert, S. C. (2007). Cultivating “natural” cultural districts. Creativity&Change. Social Impact of the Arts Project, University of Pennsylvania’s School of Social Policy & Practice.
Retrieved from <nowiki>http://www.trfund.com/resource/downloads/creativity/NaturalCulturalDistricts.pdf</nowiki> </ref> If the conception of a cultual district as a complex adaptive system were accepted, the design process would be conceived as something more flexible, dynamic and in evolution. Complexity theory and complex adaptive systems should move understanding of supra-urban cultural districts towards a more holistic and bottom-up approach<ref name="Lazzeretti 635–648"/><ref>{{Cite journal|title = Cultural Districts, A New Strategy for Regional Development? The South-East Cultural District in Sicily|url = https://dx.doi.org/10.1080/00343400903427936|journal = Regional Studies|date = 2010-08-01|issn = 0034-3404|pages = 905–917|volume = 44|issue = 7|doi = 10.1080/00343400903427936|first = Antoine Le|last = Blanc}}</ref> rather than a linear top-down approach to analysis and design. This does not suggest inhibiting any attempt at prediction or planning. The use of qualitative analysis and rough estimations or agent-based modelling can represent a fertile ground for both future research, policy-making and managerial implications.<ref name=":0"/>
==Examples of cultural districts in the US== *[[Cultural District, Pittsburgh]], started in 1984 *[[Indianapolis Cultural Districts]] *East Fourth street Cultural District, Manhattan, led by [[Fourth Arts Block]] *A cultural district is being created in Brooklyn, NY see [http://www.nysun.com/new-york/mixed-use-facility-planned-for-brooklyn-cultural/80055/ Article from The Sun] *[http://www.lpccd.org Lincoln Park Coast Cultural District, NJ] *[http://www.cityblm.org Bloomington Cultural District, Illinois] *[http://valleyarts.org/blog/?page_id=1333Harrisonburg's Cultural District, Virginia]{{dead link|date=August 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }} *[https://web.archive.org/web/20080905225233/http://www.rooseveltculturaldistrict.com/about.html Roosevelt Cultural District, Des Moines, Iowa] *[https://web.archive.org/web/20090226233154/http://www.crt.state.la.us/culturaldistricts Louisiana Cultural Districts] *[http://www.fairfieldculturaldistrict.org/contact.htm Fairfield Cultural District, Iowa] *[http://mvcd.org/about_us.aspx Baltimore's Mont Vernon Cultural District]

{{Infobox person | name = Dentaa | image = Entrepreneur, TV presenter and GUBA Awards founder Dentaa Amoateng.jpg | image_size = | caption = | birth_name = Dentaa Amoateng | birth_date = 1983 | birth_place = [[Juaso|Juaso, Ghana]] | television = The Dentaa Show | occupation = Television presenter, actress, singer, entrepreneur | years_active = 1995–present | nationality = [[Ghanaian]] | residence = London, UK | alma mater = Buckinghamshire New University }}
'''Akosua Dentaa Amoateng''' [[Order of the British Empire|MBE]] (born 1983), best known by her [[stage name]] '''Dentaa''', is an award-winning [[Ghanaians in the United Kingdom|British Ghanaian]] [[entrepreneur]], [[actress]], [[TV presenter]], [[singer]], [[TV producer|producer]] and [[sports agent|manager]]. She was awarded an [[MBE]] in Her Majesty The Queen; [[Elizabeth II]]'s 2016 Birthday Honors,<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.gov.uk/government/world-location-news/dentaa-amoateng-honoured-by-her-majesty-the-queen |title=Dentaa Honored by British Monarch |accessdate=27 June 2016}}</ref> a year later in 2017 she received the Ghana Peace Awards Humanitarian Service Laureate in Accra, Ghana.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.modernghana.com/amp/entertainment/46115/ghana-peace-awards-rtp-awards-stacy-amoateng-sweeps-two-b.html |title=Ghana Peace Awards & RTP Awards: Stacy Amoateng Sweeps Two Big Awards On Saturday|accessdate=29 November 2017}}</ref>
As an actress she appeared on British TV shows including [[EastEnders]] and [[Holby City]], before moving into presenting, hosting television programmes on British and Ghanaian TV including The Dentaa Show and reality TV music competition Mentor IV. She also had a brief career as a singer, releasing a [[Gospel music|gospel album]] in 2005, "Wu Ye Nyame".
Dentaa is an advocate for the Ghanaian community in the [[UK]] and in 2017 she was put on the list of 100 ''Most Outstanding Women Entrepreneurs in Ghana'' for her advocacy by ''The African Network of Entrepreneurs'' <ref>{{cite web|url=http://womanrising.org/100mowe/|title=100 Most Outstanding Women in Ghana|accessdate=29 November 2017}}</ref>. In 2009 she founded the GUBA (Ghanaian UK Based Achievements) Awards,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.theafricandream.net/dentaa-mbe-status-guba-african-dream/ |title=GUBA |accessdate=27 June 2016}}</ref> which recognises the achievements of individuals and organisations "positively contributing to the Ghanaian community in the UK or Ghana".<ref name="Africa News">{{cite web |url=http://www.africanews.com/site/GUBA_awards_Celebrating_Ghanaian_achievements/list_messages/39868 |title=GUBA awards: Celebrating Ghanaian achievements |author=Kent Mensah |publisher=Africa News.com |date=26 September 2011 |accessdate=9 November 2012 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20111003201314/http://www.africanews.com/site/GUBA_awards_Celebrating_Ghanaian_achievements/list_messages/39868 |archivedate=3 October 2011 |df=dmy-all }}</ref> In 2011, she was named in [http://future100awards.wordpress.com/ The Future 100 Awards] as a "Young Social Entrepreneur" of the year for her work with GUBA.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://future100awards.wordpress.com/future-100-winners-2011/future-100-2011-winners-full-summary/ |title=Future 100 2011 Winners – Full Summary |accessdate=2 January 2013}}</ref>
In June 2013, Dentaa was announced as the winner of the annual African Women in Europe (AWE) Award, for her work in promoting Ghanaian achievement in the UK and for her charity work. Organisers described her as an "icon and role model to all African women living and working in Europe".<ref name="AWE">{{cite web|url=http://www.voice-online.co.uk/article/guba-founder-wins-2013-african-women-europe-gong |title=GUBA founder wins 2013 African Women in Europe gong |author=Melissa Allison-Forbes |publisher=The Voice |date=25 June 2013 |accessdate=5 July 2013}}</ref>
Dentaa is currently based in [[London, England]].<ref name="Album">{{cite web|url=http://www.modernghana.com/music/2478/3/dentaas-eagerly-awaited-debut-album.html |title=Dentaa's Eagerly-awaited Debut Album |author=Nii Atakora Mensah |publisher=Modern Ghana |date=12 July 2005 |accessdate=3 December 2012}}</ref>
==Early years==
Dentaa was born in [[Juaso]], in the Ashanti Region of [[Ghana]], but moved with her family to the UK at the age of five. From a young age she enjoyed performing in school plays and talent shows. She took her [[GCSE]]s at the [[Walthamstow School for Girls]] and A Levels ([[Media Studies]], [[Sociology]] and [[Performing Arts]]) at the [[Leyton Sixth Form College]]. She went on to study for a degree in [[paediatric nursing]] at [[Buckinghamshire New University]].<ref name="Jamati">{{cite web|url=http://www.jamati.com/online/film/keeping-up-with-dentaa/ |title=Keeping Up With Dentaa |author=Ameyaw Debrah |publisher=Jamati.com |date=10 February 2008 |accessdate=3 December 2012}}</ref>
== Music and TV Work ==
Between the late 1990s and early 2000s, Dentaa appeared on British TV dramas including EastEnders, Holby City, [[Judge John Deed]], Run Baby Run, and [[Prime Suspect]].<ref name="Joy">{{cite web|url=http://entertainment.myjoyonline.com/pages/news/200705/5120.php |title=Dentaa retires from music |publisher=My Joy Online |date=29 August 2007 |accessdate=3 December 2012}}</ref><ref name="Ghana Celebrities">{{cite web|url=http://www.ghanacelebrities.com/2010/03/19/congratulationsdentaa-gives-birth-to-another-cute-baby-boy |title=Congratulations:Dentaa Gives Birth to Another Cute Baby Boy |author=Chris-Vincent Agyapong Febiri |publisher=Ghana Celebrities.com |date=19 March 2010 |accessdate=3 December 2012}}</ref>
In 2005, she released a gospel album entitled "Wu Ye Nyame", through Alordia Promotions and Goodies Music Production. The album received airplay on radio stations in Ghana and Dentaa supported the release with a global tour.<ref name="Album" /><ref name="Jamati" />
=== The Dentaa Show ===
In 2006, Dentaa produced and fronted a new TV show for British ethnic minority channel [[OBE TV|OBE (Original Black Entertainment) TV]] called "The Dentaa Show". The 30-minute syndicated magazine programme, broadcast on [[Sky (UK and Ireland)|Sky]] Channel 155, was filmed in front of a live audience and split into three segments exploring the Ghanaian and African entertainment scene through interviews with celebrities, coverage of entertainment events and a focus on the latest music chart videos.<ref name="Joy" /> The show was Ghana's most-watched entertainment programme.<ref name="Ambassador">{{cite journal |journal=The Ambassador |year=2010 |volume=1 |issue=1 |page=11 |title=GUBA to honour Ghanaian businesses in the UK |author=Davis, Rickie |url=http://issuu.com/magazineproduction/docs/ambassadormag_ezine |accessdate=3 December 2012 }}</ref> and in its first year, scored the highest ratings in first-run syndication in the 18 – 40 years [[demographic]], out-performing established [[talk shows]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.modernghana.com/music/16065/3/dentaa-show-to-hit-your-screens.html |title=Dentaa Show To Hit Your Screens |publisher=Modern Ghana |date=31 August 2011 |accessdate=3 December 2012}}</ref> The Dentaa Show ran for three seasons.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.voiceofafricaradio.com/faces-of-the-week/432-faces-week-12-2010.html |title=Faces of the Week |publisher=Voice of Africa Radio |accessdate=3 December 2012 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20121130021300/http://voiceofafricaradio.com/faces-of-the-week/432-faces-week-12-2010.html |archivedate=30 November 2012 |df=dmy }}</ref>
=== Other TV shows and hosting appearances ===
Dentaa co-hosted Miss Ghana UK in 2007<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ghanaweb.com/GhanaHomePage/NewsArchive/artikel.php?ID=129910 |title=Mzbel, Wutah, FBS storm U.K |publisher=GhanaWeb |date=31 August 2007 |accessdate=3 December 2012}}</ref> and the following year became a co-host on the fourth series of Mentor — Ghana's equivalent of [[The X Factor (TV series)|The X-Factor]]<ref name="Ambassador"/> — on Ghanaian TV channel [[TV3 Ghana|TV3]], alongside Kofi Okyere Darko (aka "KOD").<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.modernghana.com/music/8492/3/tv3-mentor-returns.html |title=TV3 Mentor Returns |author=Ameyaw Debrah |publisher=Modern Ghana|date=6 December 2008 |accessdate=3 December 2012}}</ref> In 2009 she co-hosted the Ghana Music Awards, performing a duet with [[Batman Samini]], and in 2010 presented Ghana's first make-over show, Darling Beauty Diaries. She did not, however, return for the fifth series of Mentor in 2010 as she was by then pregnant with her second child.<ref name="Ghana Celebrities" />
In August 2012, it was announced that Dentaa would be making a return to TV with new weekly show '''Dinner with Dentaa''', which features celebrity guests cooking for her.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ameyawdebrah.com/dinner-with-dentaa-coming-soon/ |title= Dinner with Dentaa coming soon! |author=[[Ameyaw Debrah]] |publisher=Modern Ghana |date=30 August 2012 |accessdate=3 December 2012}}</ref>
== GUBA Awards ==
{{main article|Ghana UK-Based Achievement Awards}}
Outside of broadcasting, Dentaa is known as the founder and [[CEO]] of non-profit organisation the Ghana UK Based Achievement (GUBA) Awards which organises an annual [[awards ceremony]] in Britain recognising the ‘hugely significant’ contribution that British-Ghanaians make to society.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.voice-online.co.uk/article/tony-and-cherie-blair-back-guba-awards |title=Tony and Cherie Blair back GUBA awards |publisher=The Voice |date=30 October 2012 |accessdate=3 December 2012}}</ref> Dentaa founded the awards in 2009 with the first awards ceremony taking place in London, England, in October 2010.<ref name="Fab">{{cite web|url=http://fabmagazineonline.com/fab-event-guba-2012-so-far/ |title=FAB Event: GUBA 2012 So Far |author=Claudia Andrews |publisher=Fab Magazine |date=4 November 2012 |accessdate=3 December 2012}}</ref> Dentaa, who describes herself as a "proud Ghanaian", had the idea to set up the awards as she felt that there was "nothing out there promoted and enriched my heritage".
GUBA was the first ceremony of its kind to specifically recognise Ghanaian achievement<ref name="Africa News" /> and has since been endorsed by dignitaries and organisations including The Ghana High Commission to the UK & Ireland, The British High Commission in Ghana, The Ghana Ministry of Tourism, former British Prime Minister [[Tony Blair]] and wife [[Cherie Blair|Cherie]], [[Paul Boateng|Lord Paul Boateng]], [[Diane Abbott|Diane Abbott MP]] and [[FIFA]] President [[Sepp Blatter]].<ref name="Fab" />
Dentaa's achievements with GUBA were acknowledged in 2011 when she was announced as one of the "Young Social Entrepreneurs of the Year" in the annual Future 100 Awards, and again in 2013 when she received the African Women in Europe (AWE) Award.<ref name="AWE" /><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.modernghana.com/music/16632/3/dentaa-of-speak-to-dentaa-guba-awards-named-one-of.html |title=Dentaa of Speak To Dentaa & GUBA Awards named one of the Future 100 Young Social Entrepreneurs for 2011 |publisher=Modern Ghana |date=15 November 2011 |accessdate=3 December 2012}}</ref> Dentaa has recently been nominated for two categories at the annual Women4Africa awards to be held in London in May 2014
== Connection with professional football ==
Dentaa has a strong connection to the world of football. She is the Manager of Ghana and former [[Sunderland FC|Sunderland]] [[Striker (football)|striker]] [[Asamoah Gyan]], and played an "influential role" in helping Ghana's national football team, popularly known as the [[The Black Stars|Black Stars]], secure the services of [[Arsenal FC|Arsenal]] [[midfielder]] [[Emmanuel Frimpong]].<ref name="List">{{cite web|url=http://www.modernghana.com/music/16355/3/guba-ceo-dentaa-makes-the-list.html |title=GUBA CEO Dentaa makes the List |author=Kay Sarpong |publisher=Modern Ghana |date=6 October 2011 |accessdate=3 December 2012}}</ref>
In May 2012, she organised the launch of the Benjani Mwaruwari Foundation, set up by [[Portsmouth FC|Portsmouth]] and [[Zimbabwe national football team]] striker [[Benjani Mwaruwari]] to build a [[football academy]] for [[Underprivileged children|underprivileged youths]] in [[Zimbabwe]].<ref name="Filla">{{cite web|url=http://www.ghanafilla.net/dentaa-to-host-benjani-mwaruwari-foundation-in-zimbabwe-with-guest-appearances-by-emmanuel-adebayor-yaya-and-kolo-toure-kanu-and-jay-jay-okocha/ |title=Dentaa to host Benjani Mwaruwari Foundation in Zimbabwe |publisher=GhanaFilla.net |date=26 May 2012 |accessdate=3 December 2012}}</ref> The following month, in June 2012, Dentaa helped the Arthur Wharton Foundation present a statuette of [[Arthur Wharton]] — the first professional black football player — to [[FIFA]] President Sepp Blatter.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.caribdirect.com/2012/06/11/first-black-professional-footballer-arthur-wharton-honoured-by-guba-and-fifa/ |title=First black professional footballer, Arthur Wharton honoured by GUBA and FIFA |publisher=GhanaFilla.net |date=7 June 2012 |accessdate=3 December 2012}}</ref> The Arthur Wharton Marquette Statue is now displayed in the presidents' lounge at FIFA headquarters in [[Zurich]].<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-england-tees-18340408 |title=World's first black professional footballer Arthur Wharton honoured |publisher=BBC.co.uk |date=7 June 2012 |accessdate=3 December 2012}}</ref>
Dentaa's work in the sporting arena was recognised in 2011, when she was nominated for the 2011 Black List Awards — a UK-based awards scheme that acknowledges the contribution of the black community for achievements across all levels of football, and which is supported by [[the Football Association]], [[Professional Footballers' Association]] and Black Collective of Media in Sport (BCOMS), among others. Her management of Gyan and influence in the signing of Frimpong to the Ghana national team were "key factors" in her nomination.<ref name="List" />

[[File:Bridge-spouted Bottle with Anthropomorphic Mythical Being - warrior, 100-300 AD, Nasca culture, south coast Peru, earthenware with colored slips - Gardiner Museum, Toronto - DSC01301.JPG|thumb|A bridge-spouted bottle from the [[Nasca culture]], 100-300 AD]]
[[File:Nazca-pottery-(01).png|thumb|[[Huaco (pottery)|Huaco]] figurative vessel of this form]]
The '''double spout and bridge vessel''' was a form of usually<ref>There are a few late silver or gold examples, such as the ones illustrated [http://culturalheritage.state.gov/peru/metal/0000001a.htm here] and [http://www.latinamericanstudies.org/chimu/vessel.gif here] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110610155621/http://www.latinamericanstudies.org/chimu/vessel.gif |date=June 10, 2011 }}</ref> [[ceramic]] [[drinking vessel|drinking container]] developed sometime before 500 BC by [[Indigenous peoples of the Americas|indigenous]] groups on the [[Peru]]vian coast.<ref>[http://www.metmuseum.org/toah/ho/04/sac/ho_62.266.72.htm "Whistling bottle with feline face [Peru; Paracas] (62.266.72)".] In Heilbrunn Timeline of Art History. New York: The [[Metropolitan Museum of Art]], 2000–.(October 2006) Retrieved 11 May 2009</ref> True to its name, this type of [[bottle]] is distinguished by two spouts with a handle bridging them. First used by the [[Paracas culture]], it was later adopted by the [[Nazca culture|Nazca]]. While at first the Paracas tended to incise designs derived from the art of the [[Chavin culture]] on the surface of the vessels,<ref>[http://collections.lacma.org/node/197367 ''Covered Double Spout and Bridge Vessel, 800-100 B.C.'' Entry on the website of the LACMA] retrieved 11 May 2009</ref> later on they began to treat the vessel as a sculptural form, an advance facilitated by developments in ceramic technology that allowed them construct vessels with thinner walls.<ref>[http://www.metmuseum.org/toah/ho/04/sac/ho_63.232.55.htm "Gourd bottle [Peru; Topará] (63.232.55)".] In Heilbrunn Timeline of Art History. New York: The Metropolitan Museum of Art, 2000–. (October 2006) Retrieved 11 May 2009</ref> This tradition was continued by the Nazca, whose vessels were elaborately figurative (see illustration below right), decorated with polychrome glazes, or both.
The vessels were constructed by the [[coiling (pottery)|coil method]]. The Nazca would then apply multicolored [[slip (ceramics)|slip]] to achieve polychrome effects before the vessels were fired, an advance over the Paracas, who had painted the vessels with resins after firing. The Nazca technique allowed for much brighter and more permanent colors, whose sheen was enhanced by burnishing after the vessel was fired.<ref name = "Brit">[https://www.britishmuseum.org/explore/highlights/highlight_objects/aoa/d/double_spout_and_bridge_vessel.aspx ''Double spout and bridge vessel with hummingbirds''], on the Website of the British Museum. Retrieved 11 May 2009. Slip firing fuses the pigmented minerals with the clay itself, while resin simply sat on the surface, and as an organic material was subject to decay</ref>
Both the Paracas and the Nazca appear to have used this type of vessel for ritual purposes, as they are most often found in graves.<ref name = "Brit" />
==See also== *[[Stirrup spout vessel]] *[[Bridge spouted vessel]], a similarly named but unrelated Mediterranean vessel form

{{Infobox historic building | name = Emamieh school | native_name = مدرسه امامیه | native_name_lang = fa | former_names = | alternate_names = Baba Ghassem school | status = Cultural | image = | image_alt = | caption = | map_type = Iran | map_alt = | map_caption = Location within [[Iran]] | embedded = | altitude = | building_type = [[school]] | architectural_style = [[Azeri style|Azeri]] | structural_system = | cost = | client = Soltan Abolhassan Talout Damghani | owner = | current_tenants = | landlord = | location = [[Isfahan]], [[Iran]] | address = | coordinates = {{coord|32.6611|51.6841|region:IR|display=inline,title}} | groundbreaking_date = | start_date = | completion_date = | completed_date = | opened_date = | height = | floor_count = | floor_area = | url = | references = }} The '''Emamieh school''' is a historical school in [[Isfahan]], [[Iran]]. The school belongs to the 14th century and was built by the order of ''Soltan Abolhassan Talout Damghani''. He built the school for his teacher ''Baba Ghassem Esfahani''. The building was [[tile]]d by the ''Sheikh Mohammad ebn-e Omar'', whose name was mentioned on the [[inscription]]s of the school.<ref>http://arthut.co/school/item/590-emamiyeh-madrasa</ref>

revision.text:
{{Use British English|date=September 2014}} {{Use dmy dates|date=September 2014}} {{Infobox artist | name = Eric Newton | image = Eric Newton.jpg | image_size = | alt = | caption = | birth_name = Eric Oppenheimer | birth_date = 28 April 1893 | birth_place = [[Marple Bridge]], Manchester | death_date = 10 March 1965 | death_place = London | nationality = British | spouse = [[Stella Mary Newton|Stella Mary Pearce]] | field = | training = University of Manchester | movement = | works = | patrons = | awards = | elected = | website = <!-- {{URL|Example.com}} --> | bgcolour = }}
'''Eric Newton''' (1893–1965) was an English artist, writer, broadcaster and art critic. He produced several books in addition to his newspaper and radio work and created mosaics for Ludwig Oppenheimer Ltd, mostly on a religious theme. His radio broadcasts made him well known to the British public in the 1930s.
==Career== After gaining a BA from [[Manchester University]] in 1913, he worked as a designer at Ludwig Oppenheimer Ltd, the [[mosaic]] firm founded by his grandfather and based in Old Trafford, Manchester. His work, and that of the Oppenheimer firm is still to be seen in several churches in Britain and Ireland. He took part in the [[International Exposition of Modern Industrial and Decorative Arts|Paris exhibition]] in 1925.<ref name=obittimes>{{Cite news |title=Obituary. Mr. Eric Newton |newspaper=The Times |date=11 March 1965}}</ref>
He is best known as an art critic and writer. He was appointed art critic of the [[Manchester Guardian]] in 1930, although he had provided copy for that paper for some years prior to this. He was art critic for [[The Times]] for three years from 1947,<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.dictionaryofarthistorians.org/newtone.htm | title=Dictionary of Art Historians. E. Newton}}</ref> and wrote frequently for the [[New York Times]], [[Time and Tide (magazine)|''Time and Tide'']] magazine<ref>{{Cite news |title=Eric Newton, 71, London Art Critic. Newsman, author, Teacher and Lecturer Is Dead |newspaper=The New York Times |date=11 March 1965}}</ref> and [[ArtReview]]<ref name="art review twitter">{{cite web |url=https://twitter.com/ArtReview_/status/895275374342537217 |title=''ArtReview 'Thoughts about promise'' Eric Newton}}</ref>
Newton delivered radio lectures on art, notably the 1935 [[British Broadcasting Corporation|BBC]] 12 part series "The Artist and his Public" subsequently turned into the first of several books.<ref name=Rfield>{{cite web |title=''L. Oppenheimer Ltd and the Mosaics of Eric Newton.''|url=http://www.tilesoc.org.uk/events/conference2006/papers/pdf/field.pdf Robert Field}}</ref><ref>{{cite book |last= |first= |year= 1935 |title= The artist and His Public |url= |location= |publisher=Allen & Unwin |isbn= |accessdate= }}</ref> and took part in the radio arts series ''The Critics''. In this programme, his Times Obituary states "his lucidity and critical sense were trenchantly displayed".<ref name=obittimes /> The Oxford Dictionary of Art describes him as "a clear and polished writer and also an articulate lecturer and radio broadcaster".<ref>{{cite book |last= |first= |year= 1952 |title= Oxford Dictionary of Art |url= |location= |publisher=OUP |isbn=978-0-19-172762-7 |accessdate= }}</ref>
These broadcasts made his name well known and local newspaper archives reveal that Newton was clearly in demand, delivering public lectures across the country in the late 1930s and 1940s. <ref>{{cite news |date=26 March 1942 |title= Modern Painting Exhibition at Plymouth. Tomorrow Mr. Eric Newton ... is lecturing |newspaper=Western Morning News}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |date=11 May 1942 |title=Presentation To Art Galleries ... lecture on art by Eric Newton on Sunday, May 24th |newspaper=Dundee Courier}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |date=30 May 1947 |title=Mr Eric Newton (art critic) will open the first loan exhibition of the Association of Friends of the Bristol Art Gallery to-morrow |newspaper=Western Daily Press }}</ref>
Newton undertook lecture tours to North America in 1937, 1953 and 1956, the 1937 tour of Canada was sponsored by the [[National Gallery of Canada]]. His diary of this tour was subsequently published (see below). The 1956 tour included the [[Memorial University of Newfoundland]] where he lectured on modern art. A photograph exists in the university archives.<ref>{{cite web |title=Eric Newton visits the University to lecture on Modern Art :: S.J. Carew Photograph Collection|url=http://collections.mun.ca/u?/sjcarew,843 |accessdate=9 September 2014}}</ref> Newton was lecturer in art history at the [[Central School of Art and Design|Central School of Art and crafts]] from 1963.<ref name=obittimes />
His MA, completed in 1951 at Manchester was on the subject of the renaissance artist [[Tintoretto]],<ref>{{cite thesis |degree=M.A. |first=Eric |last=Newton |title=Tintoretto and the Scuolo and Church of San Rocco, Venice.|publisher=Manchester University |year=1951 |docket=Th8458}}</ref> and was subsequently published in 1952 as a book.<ref>{{cite book |last= |first= |year= 1952 |title= Tintoretto |url= |location= |publisher=Longmans, Green |isbn=978-0-8371-4501-3 |accessdate= }}</ref>
Newton was [[Slade Professor of Fine Art#Slade Professors, Oxford University|Slade Professor of Fine Art]] at [[Oxford University|Oxford]] in 1959<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.hoa.ox.ac.uk/fileadmin/hoa/documents/pdf/Oxford_Slade_Professors.pdf |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2017-03-08 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150213123228/http://www.hoa.ox.ac.uk/fileadmin/hoa/documents/pdf/Oxford_Slade_Professors.pdf |archivedate=13 February 2015 |df=dmy-all }}</ref><ref>''The Times'', 15 April 1958 p 8</ref> and art adviser to the [[Commonwealth Institute]] from 1960 to 1963. He was president of the British Section of the [[International Association of Art Critics]] between 1949 and 1961.<ref name=obittimes />
While he left the family firm, he continued to create mosaics for much of his life, those in the side chapels of [[Sacred Heart Church, Hillsborough|Sacred Heart Church]] Sheffield being installed in 1961. The [[Courtauld Institute of Art]] holds many designs of Newton Mosaics and theatre set designs in its Stella Newton Archive.<ref>{{cite web |title=Courtauld Institute of Art Newsletter Feb 2010 |url=http://www.courtauld.ac.uk/booklibrary/collections_services/documents/2010-02Newsletter.pdf |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100921200623/http://courtauld.ac.uk/booklibrary/collections_services/documents/2010-02Newsletter.pdf |archivedate=21 September 2010 |df=dmy }}</ref>
==Personal life== Newton was born in 1893 to Lehmann James Oppenheimer and Edith née Newton. His mother was from [[Heaton Mersey]].<ref>1911 census</ref> In 1908 he was awarded a Foundation Scholarship to [[Hulme Grammar School]] from [[William Hulme#Hulme.27s Charity|Hulme's Charity]].<ref>{{Cite news |title=Hulme's Charity |newspaper=Manchester Courier |date=1 October 1908}}</ref> After graduation from Manchester University, he served in the army during the [[First World War]], joining the [[Manchester Regiment]] as a 2nd Lieutenant from the Manchester University Contingent of the [[Officer Training Corps]] on 14 November 1914.<ref>{{London Gazette |issue=28973 |date=13 November 1914 |page=9276 }}</ref> He was promoted to temporary captain in September 1915.<ref>{{London Gazette |issue=29312 |date=1 October 1915 |page=9664 }}</ref> His medal card suggests he served in France and was awarded the [[Victory Medal (United Kingdom)|Victory Medal]] and [[British War Medal]].<ref>[[National Archives (UK)|National Archives]] Catalogue Reference:WO/372/14</ref>
His father (also a mosaic manufacturer in the family firm) served as a lieutenant in the London Regiment ([[Artists Rifles|Artists' Rifles]]) and died in 1916<ref>{{cite web|url=https://archive.org/stream/regimentalrollof00highiala#page/10/mode/2up|title=The regimental roll of honour and war record of the Artists' Rifles (1/28th, 2/28th and 3/28th battalions, the London Regiment T. F.) Commissions, promotions, appointments and rewards for service in the field obtained by members of the corps since 4th August, 1914|accessdate=9 September 2014}}</ref> having been gassed. Lehmann is buried in the [[Boulogne]] Eastern Cemetery (Grave ref VII. B. 11.).<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.cwgc.org/find-war-dead/casualty/48333/OPPENHEIMER,%20LEHMANN%20JAMES|title=CWGC - Casualty Details|author=Reading Room Manchester|accessdate=9 September 2014}}</ref>
Though the [[London Gazette]] records the recruitment of "Eric Newton Oppenheimer", and promotion of "Eric N. Oppenheimer", it was after the war that he formally changed his name from Oppenheimer to his mother's maiden name of Newton, the latter sounding less German. He married his first wife, Isabel Aileen Vinicombe on 29 November 1915 at the Church of St James, Birch in [[Rusholme]],.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.lan-opc.org.uk/Manchester/Rusholme/stjames/marriages_1896-1921.html|title=Lancashire OnLine Parish Clerk Project |accessdate=9 September 2014}}</ref> the couple divorced in 1934 after which Newton married the fashion designer [[Stella Mary Newton|Stella Mary Pearce]]. The couple moved to London, living at 3 Cumberland Gardens. Newton died in his London office in 1965.
==Publications== *{{cite book |last= |first= |year= 1935 |title= The artist and His Public |url= |location= |publisher=Allen & Unwin |asin=B00086F78Q |accessdate= }} *{{cite book |last= |first= |year= 1941 |title= European Painting and Sculpture |url= |location= |publisher=Pelican Books |asin=B0017903UA |accessdate= }} *{{cite book |last= |first= |year= 1945 |title= War Through Artists Eyes' |url= |location= |publisher=John Murray |asin=B0007ILK7M |accessdate= }} *{{cite book |last= |first= |year= 1949 |title= An introduction to European painting. |url= |location= |publisher=Longmans, Green |asin=B0000CHR6W |accessdate= }} *{{cite book |last= |first= |year= 1950 |title= The meaning of beauty |url= |location= |publisher= Whittlesey House |isbn= |accessdate= }} *{{cite book |last= |first= |year= 1950 |title=In My View |url= |location= |publisher=Longmans, Green |asin=B00086F78Q |accessdate= }} *{{cite book |last= |first= |year= 1952 |title= Tintoretto |url= |location= |publisher=Longmans, Green |isbn=978-0-8371-4501-3 |accessdate= }} *{{cite book |last= |first= |year= 1962 |title= The Romantic Rebellion |url= |location= |publisher=Longman & Co |asin= B0000CLJYB |accessdate= }} *{{cite book |last= |first= |year= 1963 |title= The Arts of Man |url= |location= |publisher=Thames and Hudson |isbn= |accessdate= }} *{{cite book |last= |first= |year= 1966 |title=The Christian faith in art |url= |location= |publisher=Hodder & Stoughton |isbn=978-0-340-02732-5 |accessdate= }} (with William Neil) *{{cite book |last= |first= |year= 1997 |title=The Diary of English Art Critic Eric Newton on a North American Lecture Tour in 1937 |url= |location= |publisher=Edwin Mellen Press |isbn=978-0-7734-8550-1 |accessdate= }} (with John Batts, Editor)
==Mosaic works== [[File:SHapse.jpg|thumbnail|right|Eric Newton Mosaic in the apse of Sacred Heart, Hillsborough in Sheffield]] * [http://stjohns.rochdale.dofs.org.uk/heritage/ St John the Baptist, Rochdale.] Sanctuary and Apse.<ref>{{NHLE|num=1376506 |desc= CHURCH OF ST JOHN THE BAPTIST|accessdate=18 November 2013}}</ref> * [[Sacred Heart Church, Hillsborough]]. Apse and side-chapels<ref>{{NHLE|num=1254817 |desc= CHURCH OF SACRED HEART|accessdate=18 November 2013}}</ref> * Our Lady and St Edward, RC Church, Chiswick<ref name=obittimes /> * [[Honan Chapel]], Cork * [[Royal Hospital School]] Chapel, Holbrook * [http://st-colmcilles.net/ Saint Colmcille's] Church, East Belfast
==References== {{Reflist|colwidth=30em}}
